title: Corrected QT Interval (QTc)
description: Corrects QT interval for heart rate extremes using multiple validated formulas (Bazett, Fridericia, Framingham, Hodges, or Rautaharju)

ranges.interpretation: QTc ≤320 ms is diagnostic for Short QT Syndrome and associated with increased risk of sudden cardiac death
QTc 320-360 ms may suggest Short QT Syndrome when combined with additional clinical criteria
QTc within normal limits for both men and women
QTc borderline prolonged for males; consider clinical context and monitoring

ranges.description: Prolonged for males, borderline for females
ranges.interpretation: QTc prolonged for males; borderline for females. Clinical correlation recommended
QTc prolonged for both sexes. Increased risk of arrhythmias; evaluate for causes
QTc ≥480 ms diagnostic for Long QT Syndrome regardless of symptoms. High arrhythmic risk
QTc >500 ms indicates very high risk of torsades de pointes and sudden cardiac death

references: Bazett HC. An analysis of the time-relations of electrocardiograms. Heart. 1920;7:353-370.
Fridericia LS. Die Systolendauer im Elektrokardiogramm bei normalen Menschen und bei Herzkranken. Acta Med Scand. 1920;53:469-486.
Sagie A, Larson MG, Goldberg RJ, Bengtson JR, Levy D. An improved method for adjusting the QT interval for heart rate (the Framingham Heart Study). Am J Cardiol. 1992;70(7):797-801.
Hodges M, Salerno D, Erlien D. Bazett's QT correction reviewed. Evidence that a linear QT correction for heart rate is better. J Am Coll Cardiol. 1983;1(2):694.
Rautaharju PM, Surawicz B, Gettes LS, et al. AHA/ACCF/HRS recommendations for the standardization and interpretation of the electrocardiogram. J Am Coll Cardiol. 2009;53(11):982-991.
formula: Multiple formulas available: Bazett: QTc = QT/√RR, Fridericia: QTc = QT/(RR)^(1/3), Framingham: QTc = QT + 154×(1-RR), Hodges: QTc = QT + 1.75×[(60/RR)-60], Rautaharju: QTc = QT×(120+HR)/180
notes: Bazett formula most commonly used but can over/under-correct at extreme heart rates
Fridericia and Framingham formulas often preferred for broader heart rate ranges
QTc ≥480 ms diagnostic for Long QT Syndrome regardless of symptoms
QTc >500 ms indicates high risk of torsades de pointes
QTc ≤320 ms diagnostic for Short QT Syndrome
Normal values: <450 ms (men), <460 ms (women) per ACC/HRS guidelines
